Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Flood Extent/Depth Data Identification, Acquisition, Cataloguing, and Processing
Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

A non-technical description explaining the broader significance of the project

The extreme rainfall event in Louisiana in August 2016 caught many people by surprise. Flood maps and emergency preparations were designed for overflow from the Mississippi River and tributaries, but the extent and rapidity of direct precipitation caused unanticipated behaviors in the local stream watersheds. This RAPID project will examine the extent and the timing of the flooding in order to develop an effective model of the regional response to the rainfall. These data then will be incorporated into existing models of coastal flooding caused by storm surges to develop scenarios for different types of impacts on the region. This research will help in future planning and emergency management for various weather-related impacts.


A technical description of the project

This RAPID project will generate three key products: 1) A time-independent representation of the furthest extents and maximum depths of flooding; 2) Time-dependent representations of the extent and depth of flooding; and, 3) Documentation of the methodology to directly and quickly incorporate the data into a hurricane storm surge model. The field effort will collect ephemeral data to validate flood extents and depths derived from remote sensing technologies. Science will be advanced in three key areas: 1) remote sensing algorithms for near real-time flood detection; 2) numerical implementation of coupled hydrologic and hurricane storm-surge models; and 3) the geophysics of flow for hydrologic and surge interactions over a large region.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main basis of all project outcomes of this relatively small (in terms of funding levels) grant has been the demonstration, through data acquisition and numerical modeling, of distinct regions of flooding that include both coastal and hydrologic processes. Where one process dominates the other and the areas where they overlap are of particular importance.  Many benefits stem from this basic description of the complexities of compound flooding. The basic research results in a productive stream of outcomes that will extend well beyond the life of the project. 

Intellectual merit project outcomes begin with our Geophysical Research Letters publication (https://doi.org/10.1002/2018GL077524) where we define the regions where coastal and hydrologic processes overlap as flood zone transitions. A methodology is presented that permits the delineation of the area where, for example, flood risk should be assessed with careful consideration of both coastal and hydrologic processes. The approach forms a basis for improving numerical models in low gradient coastal land margin regions, and, helps to define how return period flood risk can be assessed. From this basic research intellectual pursuits are possible that include more complete bio-geo-physical and socio-economic model advancements and analyses for present and future conditions. 

Broader impact project outcomes begin with numerous grants from Federal sources. First, and foremost, the research conducted under this project served as a conceptual basis for a successful NSF Graduate Research Fellowship application by Felix Santiago-Collazo. Felix is now pursuing his PhD under the direction of the PI with focus on numerical modeling of compound flooding. He has already submitted a comprehensive literature review to a peer-reviewed journal that when published will acknowledge this RAPID grant. The RESTORE Act Louisiana Center of Excellence is funding the PI and colleagues for ?Coupling Hydrologic, Tide and Surge Processes to Enhance Flood Risk Assessments for the Louisiana Coastal Master Plan.? The National Academies of Science and Robert Woods Johnson program has provided a grant to LSU to pursue ?Inland from the Coast: A multi-scalar approach to regional climate change responses,? on which the PI is a key personnel. More proposals are being developed (including with the new NSF Coastlines & People (CoPe) program) to pursue research that is directly based on findings from this NSF RAPID grant. 

Finally, it is important to note the influence that this fundamental research has had on state and federal agencies. Recently the governor formed a Louisiana Watershed Initiative that recognizes the importance of reassessing how flood plains are established at the coastal land margin of Louisiana. The research outcomes from this NSF RAPID grant influenced and are contributing to the effort. In addition, the PI was invited to participate in the NSF CoPe workshop in Atlanta where he shared the basic ideas from the project and received very positive response with regards to their importance to future CoPe efforts. Further, the US Army Corps of Engineers invited the PI to a workshop in Galveston that focused on how to incorporate compound flooding into design. Clearly the broader impacts of this NSF RAPID will be sustained.
